blow of failure :-( Anything you can think of that you might need to solve 
this problem I will do my best to dig up - I really need Eclipse !!! 
 
Funny however that I just installed the free version of nitroX 
"http://www.m7.com/downloadNitroX.do" INCLUDING eclipse and that works. But I 
like to be up2date and thus would like eclipse 3.2 with nitroX as a regular 
plugin rather than this...

I would like for you to try last nights N-Build (N20060106-0010) by extracting it in a clean directory.  If it does not launch cleanly then please attach the log file to this bug.  If you are wary about using nightly builds then please wait for next weeks I-Build.

The latest builds have improved error logging for unresolved bundles which should give us a better clue as to what is going wrong.  Thanks.

Plz let me know if there is anything else I can do to assist you.

Can you change the files in /home/msh/eclipse/eclipse/configuration/org.eclipse.osgi/bundles/83/1/.cp/ directory to executable (chmod +x /home/msh/eclipse/eclipse/configuration/org.eclipse.osgi/bundles/83/1/.cp/*) and see if that makes any difference?
I tried that and also a chmod 777 - but still the same error.
CC'ing Billy to see if he has seen anything like this on Linux x86_64.  Billy let me know if there is someone else who knows more about the Linux x86_64 env, thanks.

The "no such file or directory" error occurs when running an x86-64 build
of Eclipse under a 32-bit VM.  Basically, the runtime linker is trying to load
the dependencies, but it can't resolve them because it's a different architecture.

The fix is to make sure you're using an x86-64 JVM if you're running the x86-64
build of Eclipse.

I have now manually installed the amd64 bit version of java and sure it works. I recon that somewhere along the line my yum or other update utility has "upgraded" my java to a stock 32 bit version... Surely the world will be a better place when everything is 64 bit :-)

Thanx for your help and support and thanx for a great tool.
